Cytobacillus mangrovibacter is a species of bacteria that was isolated from mangrove sediment samples. It belongs to the genus Cytobacillus, which is a member of the phylum Firmicutes.

The cells of Cytobacillus mangrovibacter are rod-shaped and typically measure around 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 1.2-2.5 μm in length. They are Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, and motile, with peritrichous flagella.

Cytobacillus mangrovibacter is an aerobic bacterium, capable of growing in the presence of oxygen. It is mesophilic, with an optimal growth temperature range between 30-37°C. The bacterium can tolerate a wide range of salinities, making it well-adapted to the mangrove environment.

Biochemically, Cytobacillus mangrovibacter is able to hydrolyze starch and casein, and it can utilize a variety of carbohydrates as carbon sources, including glucose, sucrose, and xylose. The G+C content of its genomic DNA is around 50-52 mol%.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences has shown that Cytobacillus mangrovibacter is most closely related to other species within the genus Cytobacillus, but it can be distinguished from them by its unique phenotypic and genotypic characteristics.
